title: War Rug, 1979–90
dimensions: Warp x Weft: 154 x 89 cm (60 5/8 x 35 1/16 in.)
description: Prayer-rug sized carpet with dark blue ground, field and border layout, knotted fringe. The field and border both include traditional medallion and floral motifs along with weaponry, including tanks and "butterfly" landmines.
justification:
In recent years both the USSR (in 1979) and the USA (in 2001) have invaded Afghanistan in response to the threat of Islamist terrorism, and in between the Soviet withdrawal in 1989 and the current war on terrorism came a decade of brutal civil war. Through these three decades of international and civil war, Afghans have borne witness to disaster by weaving unprecedented images of battles and weaponry into their rugs. 
This earlier piece has a field and border layout and combines medallion and floral patterns with a few, discreet tanks and helicopters which are not immediately apparent. This is because most traditional oriental rugs share the same layout: a patterned center field, like a garden, framed on all sides by a protective border. The earliest war rugs, from the period of the Soviet occupation (1979-1989), often share this format. They look like typical floral carpets, until upon closer inspection one notices the tanks and helicopters neatly hidden in the body of the rug or encircling its border. Sometimes images of weapons cover the whole field of the rug, like a colourful meadow of flowers, framed by neat rows of bullets or grenades. One such popular motif is the so-called&nbsp;butterfly mine, which has become a symbol of the war since in the 1980s Russian helicopters and infantry scattered millions of these mines, also called PFM-1 mines, which have injured and killed many people.
